channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
item.description: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Department of Homeland Security is expanding its efforts to identify Americans who oppose Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

item.title: Prosecutor Seeks Dismissal of Charges Against Man Shot by ICE
item.description: A judge dropped charges against the immigrant and another man after the top federal prosecutor in Minnesota said new evidence was not consistent with the agents’ testimony.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents clashed with protesters near the site of the shooting in Minneapolis.

item.title: ICE Agents Menaced Minnesota Protesters at Their Homes, Filings Say
item.description: Protesters in Minneapolis and St. Paul said in sworn statements that they were singled out by agents who demonstrated that they knew where they lived.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich

item.title: Department of Homeland Security Shuts Down, Though Essential Work Continues
item.description: Though funding for the department ran out early Saturday, officials said its essential functions would continue.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: During previous shutdowns, the Transportation Security Administration saw a spike in resignations because employees were required to report to work without being paid.

item.title: RFK Jr. Allies Target States to Overturn Vaccine Mandates for Schools
item.description: Proponents of vaccines warn that the efforts will further dismantle the immunization infrastructure and lead to more outbreaks of disease.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: An empty classroom at the high school in Williston, N.D., during an outbreak of measles there last year.

item.title: Ramping Up Election Attacks, Trump Does Not Let Reality Get in His Way
item.description: President Trump increases his attacks when he fears an election loss. With midterm elections approaching, he has gone into overdrive as Republicans face potential losses.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Trump Administration Tells Judge It Will Release Gateway Funding
item.description: Payments for the $16 billion rail tunnel between New York City and New Jersey had been suspended for more than four months.
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGeehan
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A construction site for the Gateway mass transit project near Hudson Yards in Manhattan in February.

item.title: Who Is Jeremy Carl, Trump’s Nominee to Lead the State Department?
item.description: Jeremy Carl, President Trump’s nominee to lead the State Department’s outreach to international organizations, had a rough confirmation hearing, but he stood by his views on “whiteness.”
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeremy Carl, nominee to be an Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, at a U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington D.C., this week.

item.title: Casey Wasserman Will Sell Entertainment Agency Amid Epstein Files Fallout
item.description: Casey Wasserman, a Los Angeles entertainment executive and the head of the 2028 Olympic Games, has lost clients since his emails with Ghislaine Maxwell surfaced.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Ben Sisario and Emmanuel Morgan
item.category: Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the Olympic and Paralympic Games 2028 (LA28)
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The most recent trove of Epstein documents include flirtatious messages between Casey Wasserman and Ghislaine Maxwell, Epstein’s longtime companion, while Mr. Wasserman was married with a young family.

item.title: The Mutually Beneficial Ties Between Jeffrey Epstein and Thorbjorn Jagland
item.description: Thorbjorn Jagland, a former prime minister of Norway who led the Nobel Committee, promised influence, and the disgraced financier had gifts to give, new emails show.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Stian Lysberg Solum/NTB, via Reuters
item.media:description: Thorbjorn Jagland, center left, a former prime minister of Norway, in Oslo on Thursday. A recently released tranche of emails revealed his friendship with Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Consultants Offered Epstein Access to Top N.Y. Democrats if He Donated
item.description: Dynamic SRG repeatedly, and apparently unsuccessfully, asked the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein to donate to House races, Justice Department records show.
item.dc:creator: Jay Root and Bianca Pallaro
item.media:credit: Uma Sanghvi/Palm Beach Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Once a prominent donor to Democratic politicians, Jeffrey Epstein appears to have largely stopped giving money to campaigns after he was convicted of sex crimes in Florida in 2008.

item.title: How China Built a Chip Industry, and Why It’s Still Not Enough
item.description: More than a decade into Beijing’s push for self sufficiency, Chinese firms are producing fewer, lower-performing chips than their foreign competitors.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation complex in Shanghai. The Chinese government has spent more than $150 billion on its push to make cutting-edge chips at home.

item.title: At Munich Summit, European Leaders Agree With Trump: The Old World Order Is Over
item.description: At the Munich Security Conference, U.S. officials softened their tone but not their message: Europe should pay its own way. European leaders increasingly agree.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kay Nietfeld
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany and Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain at the Munich Security Conference on Friday.

item.title: Ocasio-Cortez Offers a Working-Class Vision in Munich, With a Few Stumbles
item.description: Speaking at Europe’s largest security conference, she tied income inequality to the rise of authoritarians and offered a forceful rebuttal to President Trump’s worldview. She also had some shaky moments.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York spoke at two panels on Friday at the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: ’The Interview’: Gisèle Pelicot Shares Her Story
item.description: In her first interview with an American media outlet, Pelicot opens up about surviving years of secret abuse — and a trial that shocked the world.
item.dc:creator: Lulu Garcia-Navarro
item.media:credit: Philip Gay for The New York Times

item.title: White House Sees Win After 2 Strong Economic Reports
item.description: Solid jobs data and a soft inflation reading for January are welcome news for President Trump. But the bigger economic picture is less encouraging.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: “President Trump has defeated Joe Biden’s inflation crisis,” a White House spokesman said this week. The bigger economic picture is more uncertain.

item.title: Crises Everywhere, but the Markets Don’t Seem to Mind
item.description: Stocks have prospered while the world has plunged into disorder, an economist says. “Keep calm and carry on” may be the best investors can do.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
item.media:credit: Chanelle Nibbelink

item.title: Au Pair Juliana Peres Magalhães Sentenced to 10 Years in Banfield Double Murder Case
item.description: Juliana Peres Magalhães, 25, had cooperated with prosecutors, who sought a lenient sentence. But the judge said the woman, who pleaded guilty to manslaughter, merited the state maximum.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner/Associated Press
item.media:description: Juliana Peres Magalhães at the Fairfax County Circuit Court in Virginia before giving her testimony last month.

item.title: How ‘The Traitors’ Builds Its Perfect Reality TV Cast
item.description: The casting executives behind the Emmy-winning reality competition reveal how they create a mad mix of modern celebrity.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli
item.media:credit: Getty Images; Bravo; Peacock

item.title: One Last Chat With David Brooks
item.description: Before leaving The Times after 22 years, David Brooks responds to readers’ questions.
item.dc:creator: New York Times Opinion
item.media:credit: Grade Solomon

item.title: The One Child Policy’s Legacy: A Surplus of Single Men
item.description: A decade after the end of the one-child policy, China has over 30 million so-called surplus men. Can this dating boot camp help them find love?
item.dc:creator: Violet Du Feng

item.title: Measles Outbreak Hits Ave Maria University in Florida
item.description: More than 40 people have fallen ill at Ave Maria University, raising fears that college campuses may soon experience more measles outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times

item.title: New Research Absolves the Woman Blamed for a Dynasty’s Ruin
item.description: A Chinese king’s infatuation with a woman was seen as the reason that a golden age collapsed. Evidence suggests climate change and internal strife played bigger roles.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Researchers digging to unearth remnants of what is believed to have been a fortified gate guarding an entrance to the capital of the Western Zhou dynasty, near Hejia Village, China, in December.

item.title: Florida Couple Arrested After Pickleball Match Turns Into a Brawl
item.description: The couple, who were banned for life from a country club in Port Orange, Fla., face felony battery charges after the fight, which involved 20 people, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Three people were injured during the fight at the Spruce Creek Country Club, and one of them was transported to a hospital, the Volusia Sheriff’s Office said.

item.title: After a Harrowing Water Rescue, Baby Is Delivered on Mother’s Birthday
item.description: Shedly Apollon was on her way to a prenatal massage when she started to feel faint while on the road. Her car veered off the highway and into a lake.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
